Legal_Issue: Whether the motion for reconsideration and extension of time can be granted under Rule 397 of the Federal Courts Rules
Governing_Law: Section 72(2)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicants sought judicial review of visa refusal and simultaneously pursued an appeal before the Immigration Appeal Division (IAD)
Court_Ruling: Motion does not meet Rule 397 criteria and violates prohibition on parallel proceedings
Claimant_Status: Applicants in immigration visa refusal case
Grounds_for_Claim: Allegation that a matter was overlooked in the original decision
Legal_Standard: Rule 397(1) of the Federal Courts Rules – allows reconsideration if a matter was overlooked or omitted
Assessment_Factor: Existence of parallel proceedings before IAD and Federal Court
Applicable_Legislation: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Section 72(2)(a)
Procedural_Issue: Filing of motion for reconsideration after denial of leave; use of written submissions without personal appearance
Review_Standard: Compliance with Rule 397 and statutory bar on parallel proceedings
Legal_Provision_Cited: Rule 397(1), Federal Courts Rules; Section 72(2)(a), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Basis: Motion for reconsideration based on alleged oversight
Governing_Rule: Rule 397 of the Federal Courts Rules
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to justify reconsideration under Rule 397
Cause_Description: Applicants sought judicial review of visa refusal and later filed a motion for reconsideration after being denied leave
Evidence_Handling: Motion heard based on written submissions
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 72(2)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – prohibition on parallel proceedings
Legal_Provision: Rule 397, Federal Courts Rules; Section 72(2)(a), IRPA
Jurisdictional_Issue: Overlap between Federal Court jurisdiction and Immigration Appeal Division
Decision_Rationale: Rule 397 does not permit using reconsideration as a substitute for appeal; parallel proceedings are statutorily prohibited
